Function/Feature ID: Function 01: Use Case Filtering Documents (by Sort Order & Tags)

Test step:
1. Navigate to Workspace.
2. Select Filter > "Newest".
3. Compare UI order with Database created_at timestamps.
Expected Result (ER): The UI displays documents matching the exact descending order of the Database timestamps.

Test step:
1. Select Filter > "A-Z".
2. Verify sorting logic for non-alphabetic characters.
Expected Result (ER): System sorts strictly by ASCII/Unicode value

Test case name: System sorts strictly by ASCII/Unicode value
Test step:
1. Click Tags button.
2. Select "Tag A".
3. Verify result count against Database query for Tag A.
Expected Result (ER): The UI count matches the Database count exactly. Documents with "Tag B" or no tags are strictly excluded.

Test step:
1. Apply a Tag filter (e.g., "Work").
2. Apply Sort > "Z-A"
Expected Result (ER): The system maintains the Tag filter (only "Work" docs shown) but reorders them Z-A. (Verifies the "filtered and/or sorted" condition ).

Test step:
1. Click Tags.
2. Select a tag that belongs to zero documents.
Expected Result (ER): The system must not show an empty list. It must revert/keep the current "Newest" list view unchanged as per the Alternative Flow.

Test step:
1. Navigate to Workspace.
2. Attempt to click Filter or Tags buttons.
Expected Result (ER): System handles the empty state gracefully (buttons disabled or showing "No options" without crashing).

Test step:
1. Click Filter > "Oldest".
2. Measure time to render.
Expected Result (ER): The list re-renders within acceptable performance limits (< 2 seconds) without timeout errors.

Test step:
1. Refresh Workspace.
2. Click Tags button.
Expected Result (ER): The deleted tag should not appear in the "available options" list.

Test step:
1. Navigate to a different page.
2. Click "Back" or return to Workspace.
Expected Result (ER): System retains the user's last selected sort order ("Z-A") rather than resetting to default (Usability/System State check).

Test step:
1. Access Workspace.
2. Open Filter options.
Expected Result (ER): The "Newest/Oldest/A-Z" dropdown renders correctly within the viewport and is clickable (verifies UI implementation of basic flow).

Function/Feature ID: Function 02: Edit Tags to a Document

Test case name: Open Tag Editor from document menu
Test step: 1. Log in with a valid user account. 2. Navigate to workspace with at least one document. 3. Click the vertical dots (⋮) of a document. 4. Click “Edit tags” in the dropdown menu.
Expected Result (ER): 1. System displays the Tag Editor dialog. 2. Available tags are listed. 3. Tags currently assigned to the document are highlighted.

Test case name: Add a new single tag to a document (no existing tags)
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document with no tags. 2. Select one tag from the available tags list. 3. Click Save.
Expected Result (ER): 1. System associates the selected tag with the document. 2. The selected tag is shown in the document’s metadata area. 3. Tag information is stored in document metadata for later filtering/search.

Test case name: Add multiple tags to a document
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document. 2. Select multiple tags (≥ 2) from the list. 3. Click Save.
Expected Result (ER): 1. All selected tags are attached to the document. 2. All selected tags appear in the metadata area. 3. Document can later be filtered/search by any of these tags.

Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document that already has ≥ 1 tag. 2. Deselect one of the currently assigned tags. 3. Keep at least one other tag selected. 4. Click Save.
Expected Result (ER): 1. Deselected tag is removed from the document. 2. Remaining tags are still associated and shown in metadata.

Test case name: Remove all tags from a document
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document that already has tags. 2. Deselect all currently assigned tags (no tag selected). 3. Click Save.
Expected Result (ER): 1. Document has no tags associated. 2. No tags are displayed in document’s metadata area. 3. Document no longer appears when filtering by any of previously removed tags.

Test case name: Cancel tag editing (no change after Cancel)
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document with existing tags. 2. Change tag selection (add or remove tags). 3. Click Cancel (or Cancel button).
Expected Result (ER): 1. Tag Editor dialog is closed. 2. No changes are applied to the document tags. 3. Metadata area still displays the original set of tags.

Test case name: Close Tag Editor via “X” button or ESC key
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for any document. 2. Modify tag selection. 3. Close the dialog using “X” icon or ESC key (depending on UI design).
Expected Result (ER): 1. Tag Editor dialog is closed. 2. Changes are not saved. 3. Original tags remain unchanged in the metadata area.

Test case name: User without permission cannot edit tags
Test step: 1. Log in with a user without permission to edit document tags. 2. Navigate to a workspace document. 3. Click the vertical dots (⋮) of the document.
Expected Result (ER): 1. Edit tags option is not visible OR 2. If clicked, system shows an appropriate error message and disallows tag editing. 3. No changes to document tags are made.

Test case name: Tags updated and usable in filtering/search
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor and add at least one new tag to a document. 2. Click Save. 3. Go to the document list view. 4. Use filter/search by the new tag.
Expected Result (ER): 1. Document appears in the result list when filtering/searching by the newly added tag. 2. Tag is visible in metadata area.

Test case name: Prevent duplicate tags on the same document
Test step: 1. Open Tag Editor for a document. 2. Try to select a tag that is already assigned (or select the same tag multiple times if UI allows). 3. Click Save.
Expected Result (ER): 1. System ensures each tag is associated only once per document. 2. In metadata area, each tag is displayed at most one time. 3. No duplicate tag entries are stored in metadata.

Test step:
1. Enter User Name: "doc "
2.Enter Password: "abcd"
3. Choose "Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER):
1. Modal closes.
2. System creates the document.
3. User is redirected to the Markdown Editor.
4. Document privacy is set to Public.

Test step:
1. Enter User Name: "doc "
2.Enter Password: "abcd"
3. Choose "Private" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER):
1. Modal closes.
2. System creates the document.
3. User is redirected to the Markdown Editor.
4. Document privacy is set to Private.

Test step:
1. Click "Add Note"
2. Enter a name that already exists in the current folder.
3. Choose "Private/Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER):
1. System does not create the document.
2. An error message is displayed (e.g., "Name already exists").
3. User remains on the modal to retry.

Test step:
1. Click "Add Note"
2. Leave the Name field empty.
3. Choose "Private/Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER): System prevents creation or truncates the name (depending on specific design spec) and shows an error.

Test case name:
Verify Max Character Length 
for Name
Test step:
1. Click "Add Note"
2. Enter a name with max allowed characters + 1.
3. Choose "Private/Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER): System prevents creation or truncates the name (depending on specific design spec) and shows an error.

Test step:
1. Click "Add Note"
2. Enter a name containing allowed special characters (e.g., hyphens, underscores).
3. Choose "Private/Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER): Document is created successfully with the exact name provided.

Test step:
1. Click "Add Note"
2. Enter a name with leading/trailing spaces.
3. Choose "Private/Public" options
4. Click "Create Note" button
Expected Result (ER): Document is created as Spaced Doc (System trims whitespace automatically).

Test step:
1. Click "Add Note".
2. Enter a name, set privacy
3. Click the "Cancel" button (or close icon).
Expected Result (ER):
1. Modal closes.
2. No document is created.
3. User returns to the Workspace view.

Test step:
1. Navigate to the Workspace view.
2. Observe the interface.
Expected Result (ER): The "Add Note" button is visible and clickable.

Test step: 1. Click the "Add Note" button.
Expected Result (ER):
A modal appears containing:
- Text field for "Document Name"
- Privacy toggle (Public/Private)
- "Create Note" button
- "Cancel" button

Test step:
1. Log in to the system.
2. Observe the workspace sidebar.
Expected Result (ER):
1. User is logged in successfully.
2. The Bookmark button is visible and clickable in the sidebar.

Test case name: Verify Basic Flow - View list with existing bookmarks
Test step:
1. Ensure the logged-in user has at least one document bookmarked.
2. Click the Bookmark button from the sidebar.
Expected Result (ER):
1. The system retrieves the data.
2. The system displays a list of bookmarked documents including titles and brief metadata.

Test case name: Verify Alternative Flow - View list with NO bookmarks
Test step:
1. Ensure the logged-in user has zero bookmarked documents.
2. Click the Bookmark button from the sidebar.
Expected Result (ER):
1. The system attempts to retrieve data.
2. The system displays the message: "No bookmarked documents found." (or similar).

Test step:
1. Click the Bookmark button.
2. Inspect the details of a specific document in the list.
Expected Result (ER):
1. The list is displayed.
2. The entry clearly shows the Document Title and metadata (e.g., Date, Author, or File Type) as per the requirements.

Test step:
1. Open the Bookmark list.
2. Click on the title of a bookmarked document.
Expected Result (ER):
1. The system navigates the user to the document view for that specific file.
2. The document opens successfully.

Test step:
1. Navigate to a document that is NOT bookmarked.
2. Add it to bookmarks.
3. Click the Bookmark button in the sidebar.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The newly added document appears at the top (or in the correct sort order) of the bookmark list immediately.

Test step:
1. Open the Bookmark list.
2. Remove a bookmark (via context menu or document view).
3. Close and re-open the Bookmark list (or refresh).
Expected Result (ER): 1. The removed document is no longer visible in the Bookmark list.

Test step:
1. View Bookmark list to confirm items exist.
2. Log out of the system.
3. Log back in.
4. Click the Bookmark button.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The list displays the exact same documents as before the logout. Data is persistent.

Test step:
1. Log in as User A and bookmark "Document X".
2. Log out and log in as User B.
3. Click the Bookmark button.
Expected Result (ER): 1. User B does NOT see "Document X" in their list (unless User B explicitly bookmarked it themselves). The list is unique to the user.

Test step:
1. Ensure the user has a large number of bookmarks (e.g., 20+).
2. Click the Bookmark button.
3. Scroll through the list.
Expected Result (ER):
1. The list loads within a reasonable time.
2. A scrollbar appears, and the layout does not break. All items are accessible.

Function/Feature ID: Function 05: Use Case Filtering Documents (By search bar)

Test case name: UI01 – Search with a keyword that has matching documents
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen with a list of documents.2. Enter a keyword such as “design” (or any keyword that is known to appear in the title/content of at least one document).3. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system queries document titles and content using the keyword.2. A list of matching documents is displayed (at least one document), clearly showing the title (and content snippet if available).3. Documents that do not match the keyword are not shown in the list.

Test case name: UI02 – Search with a keyword that has no matching documents
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Enter a keyword that does not exist in any document title/content (for example: “xyz123@@@”).3. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system queries document titles and content using the keyword.2. No documents are displayed in the list.3. The message “No results found.” is clearly displayed to the user.

Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Leave the search box empty (do not type any character).3. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system does not execute a search with an empty keyword.2. The application remains stable and does not crash.3. An error or warning message is shown asking the user to enter a search term (e.g., “Please enter a search term.”), or the current document list remains unchanged.

Test case name: UI04 – Search should match in both title and content
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Identify a document where the keyword appears only in the content and not in the title.3. Enter that keyword in the search box.4. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system queries both document titles and document content.2. The document that contains the keyword only in its content is still displayed in the result list.3. Documents that do not contain the keyword in either title or content are not shown.

Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Identify a document containing the keyword “Design” (e.g., “System Design”) in its title or content.3. Enter the keyword using different letter cases, for example “design” and “DESIGN”.4. Press Enter or click the Search icon for each variant.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system treats the search as case-insensitive.2. Documents containing “Design”, “design”, “DESIGN”, etc. are all returned in the same way.3. The search result does not change only because of different letter casing.

Test case name: UI06 – Search with leading and trailing spaces
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Enter a keyword that exists, but with spaces around it, e.g., “ design ”.3. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system trims leading and trailing spaces from the search keyword.2. The result list is the same as when searching for “design” without spaces.3. No error or unexpected behavior occurs because of the extra spaces.

Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Identify a document whose title or content contains the phrase “system design”.3. Enter “system design” into the search box.4. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system treats the whole input as a search phrase.2. Documents that contain the phrase “system design” in their title or content are displayed in the result list.3. Documents that do not contain the full phrase are not shown.

Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Identify a document whose title or content contains a term with special characters, e.g., “C++” or “Node.js”.3. Enter “C++” (or the chosen term) into the search box.4. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system correctly handles special characters in the search keyword.2. Documents containing the term with special characters (e.g., “C++”) are returned in the result list.3. No error, crash, or invalid query message occurs because of the special characters.

Test case name: UI09 – Search with Unicode / accented characters
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and is on the Markdown editor screen.2. Identify a document with a Vietnamese title or content containing a word with accents, e.g., “tài liệu”.3. Enter “tài liệu” into the search box.4. Press Enter or click the Search icon.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system supports Unicode input in the search box.2. Documents whose titles or contents contain the accented word (e.g., “tài liệu”) are correctly displayed in the result list.3. No encoding or display issues occur for accented characters.

Test case name: UI10 – Search performance under normal load
Test step: 1. Ensure the user is logged in and the system has a realistic number of documents (e.g., several hundred or more).2. Enter a common keyword into the search box.3. Press Enter or click the Search icon.4. Measure the time from submitting the search to results being fully displayed.
Expected Result (ER): 1. The system returns and renders the search results list within an acceptable response time (e.g., ≤ 2 seconds) under normal load.2. The UI remains responsive while the search is being processed.3. No timeout, freeze, or “not responding” behavior occurs during the search operation.
